DATA HANDLING.questionText: 1. A survey shows 5 students like apples, 3 like bananas, 2 like mangoes. Who is liked by most?
DATA HANDLING.explanationText: 5 students like apples, which is the most.

DATA HANDLING.questionText: 2. How many students like bananas in the survey?
3. Which fruit is liked by least students?
DATA HANDLING.explanationText: Mangoes liked by 2 students, the least.

DATA HANDLING.questionText: 4. Total students surveyed?
5. If 2 more students like mangoes, which fruit is now most liked?
DATA HANDLING.explanationText: Apples:5, Mangoes:4, Apples still most liked.

LINES AND SHAPES.questionText: 1. How many sides does a triangle have?
LINES AND SHAPES.explanationText: A triangle has 3 sides.

LINES AND SHAPES.questionText: 2. Which shape has 4 equal sides and 4 corners?
LINES AND SHAPES.explanationText: A square has 4 equal sides and 4 corners.

LINES AND SHAPES.questionText: 3. A circle has how many sides?
LINES AND SHAPES.explanationText: A circle has no sides.

LINES AND SHAPES.questionText: 4. Which line goes up and down?
LINES AND SHAPES.explanationText: A vertical line goes up and down.

LINES AND SHAPES.questionText: 5. A cube has how many faces?
LINES AND SHAPES.explanationText: A cube has 6 faces.

LINES AND SHAPES.questionText: 6. Which polygon has 5 sides?
LINES AND SHAPES.explanationText: A pentagon has 5 sides.

LINES AND SHAPES.questionText: 7. Which shape looks like a ball?
LINES AND SHAPES.explanationText: A sphere looks like a ball.

LINES AND SHAPES.questionText: 8. How many corners does a rectangle have?
LINES AND SHAPES.explanationText: A rectangle has 4 corners.

LINES AND SHAPES.questionText: 9. Which shape has 8 sides?
LINES AND SHAPES.explanationText: An octagon has 8 sides.

LINES AND SHAPES.questionText: 10. Which line is flat like the ground?
LINES AND SHAPES.explanationText: A horizontal line is flat like the ground.

LINES AND SHAPES.questionText: 11. Which shape has 3 corners?
LINES AND SHAPES.explanationText: A triangle has 3 corners.

LINES AND SHAPES.questionText: 12. Which solid shape has 2 flat faces and 1 curved face?
LINES AND SHAPES.explanationText: A cone has 2 faces (1 flat, 1 curved).

LINES AND SHAPES.questionText: 13. Which shape has no corners?
LINES AND SHAPES.explanationText: A circle has no corners.

LINES AND SHAPES.questionText: 14. Which polygon has 6 sides?
LINES AND SHAPES.explanationText: A hexagon has 6 sides.

LINES AND SHAPES.questionText: 15. Which shape looks like a dice?
LINES AND SHAPES.explanationText: A cube looks like a dice.

LINES AND SHAPES.questionText: 16. How many edges does a cube have?
LINES AND SHAPES.explanationText: A cube has 12 edges.

LINES AND SHAPES.questionText: 17. A book is shaped like which figure?
LINES AND SHAPES.explanationText: A book is shaped like a rectangle.

LINES AND SHAPES.questionText: 18. A coin is shaped like which figure?
LINES AND SHAPES.explanationText: A coin is shaped like a circle.

LINES AND SHAPES.questionText: 19. Which solid shape looks like a drum?
LINES AND SHAPES.explanationText: A cylinder looks like a drum.

LINES AND SHAPES.questionText: 20. Which shape has 7 sides?
LINES AND SHAPES.explanationText: A heptagon has 7 sides.

LINES AND SHAPES.questionText: 21. How many corners does a square have?
LINES AND SHAPES.explanationText: A square has 4 corners.

LINES AND SHAPES.questionText: 22. Which solid shape looks like an ice-cream cone?
LINES AND SHAPES.explanationText: A cone looks like an ice-cream cone.

LINES AND SHAPES.questionText: 23. Which line is sloping?
LINES AND SHAPES.explanationText: A slanting line is sloping.

LINES AND SHAPES.questionText: 24. How many sides does a rectangle have?
LINES AND SHAPES.explanationText: A rectangle has 4 sides.

LINES AND SHAPES.questionText: 25. Which shape has all sides equal but not square corners?
LINES AND SHAPES.explanationText: A rhombus has all sides equal but slant corners.

LINES AND SHAPES.questionText: 26. A traffic sign “STOP” is usually in which shape?
LINES AND SHAPES.explanationText: A STOP sign is in an octagon shape (8 sides).

LINES AND SHAPES.questionText: 27. Which solid shape looks like a football?
LINES AND SHAPES.explanationText: A football is shaped like a sphere.

LINES AND SHAPES.questionText: 28. Which polygon has 4 equal sides and opposite sides parallel?
LINES AND SHAPES.explanationText: A rectangle has opposite sides equal and parallel.

LINES AND SHAPES.questionText: 29. Which solid shape looks like a dice box?
LINES AND SHAPES.explanationText: A dice box is cube-shaped.

LINES AND SHAPES.questionText: 30. How many faces does a cone have?
LINES AND SHAPES.explanationText: A cone has 2 faces (1 flat and 1 curved).

LINES AND SHAPES.questionText: 31. Which line is round and bent?
LINES AND SHAPES.explanationText: A curved line is round and bent.

LINES AND SHAPES.questionText: 32. A clock is shaped like which figure?
LINES AND SHAPES.explanationText: A clock is usually round like a circle.

LINES AND SHAPES.questionText: 33. Which shape has 10 sides?
LINES AND SHAPES.explanationText: A decagon has 10 sides.

LINES AND SHAPES.questionText: 34. How many diagonals does a square have?
LINES AND SHAPES.explanationText: A square has 2 diagonals.

LINES AND SHAPES.questionText: 35. Which shape has all sides equal and 4 right angles?
LINES AND SHAPES.explanationText: A square has all equal sides and 4 right angles.

LINES AND SHAPES.questionText: 36. Which solid shape looks like a gas cylinder?
LINES AND SHAPES.explanationText: A gas cylinder is shaped like a cylinder.

LINES AND SHAPES.questionText: 37. How many edges does a cuboid have?
LINES AND SHAPES.explanationText: A cuboid has 12 edges.

LINES AND SHAPES.questionText: 38. Which shape has 1 curved surface and no corners?
LINES AND SHAPES.explanationText: A sphere has only 1 curved surface and no corners.

LINES AND SHAPES.questionText: 39. Which polygon has 9 sides?
LINES AND SHAPES.explanationText: A nonagon has 9 sides.

LINES AND SHAPES.questionText: 40. Which line is like a railway track?
LINES AND SHAPES.explanationText: Parallel lines are like railway tracks.

LINES AND SHAPES.questionText: 41. A slice of pizza is shaped like which figure?
LINES AND SHAPES.explanationText: A pizza slice is shaped like a triangle.

LINES AND SHAPES.questionText: 42. A door is shaped like which figure?
LINES AND SHAPES.explanationText: A door is usually rectangular.

LINES AND SHAPES.questionText: 43. Which solid shape has 6 rectangular faces?
LINES AND SHAPES.explanationText: A cuboid has 6 rectangular faces.

LINES AND SHAPES.questionText: 44. Which shape has 12 sides?
LINES AND SHAPES.explanationText: A dodecagon has 12 sides.

LINES AND SHAPES.questionText: 45. Which line never meets?
LINES AND SHAPES.explanationText: Parallel lines never meet.

LINES AND SHAPES.questionText: 46. How many corners does a cube have?
LINES AND SHAPES.explanationText: A cube has 8 corners (vertices).

LINES AND SHAPES.questionText: 47. Which shape has 1 side and no corner?
LINES AND SHAPES.explanationText: A circle has 1 curved side and no corner.

LINES AND SHAPES.questionText: 48. A tent is shaped like which solid figure?
LINES AND SHAPES.explanationText: A tent is shaped like a cone.

LINES AND SHAPES.questionText: 49. Which solid shape has 2 flat circular faces and 1 curved face?
LINES AND SHAPES.explanationText: A cylinder has 2 flat and 1 curved face.

LINES AND SHAPES.questionText: 50. Which shape has 11 sides?
LINES AND SHAPES.explanationText: A hendecagon has 11 sides.

1. The Green Plant ; Producer of Food.questionText: Q.No.39-Why do plants need to adapt?
1. The Green Plant ; Producer of Food.explanationText: Plants need to adapt both to survive and to protect themselves.

1. The Green Plant ; Producer of Food.questionText: Q.No.40-What is terrestrial plant?
1. The Green Plant ; Producer of Food.explanationText: Terrestrial plants are those that grow on land.

1. The Green Plant ; Producer of Food.questionText: Q.No.41-Tall, straight and needle–like leaves bearing plant grows on ___________.
1. The Green Plant ; Producer of Food.explanationText: Such plants grow mostly on mountains.

1. The Green Plant ; Producer of Food.questionText: Q.No.42-Pine, fir, deodar and spruce are good example of __________.
1. The Green Plant ; Producer of Food.explanationText: They are all examples of conifers.

1. The Green Plant ; Producer of Food.questionText: Q.No.43-Conifers has strong smell that keeps __________ away and protect them.
1. The Green Plant ; Producer of Food.explanationText: The strong smell of conifers protects them from insects, animals, and humans.

1. The Green Plant ; Producer of Food.questionText: Q.No.44-They shed their leaves in winter to protect themselves from cold weather.
1. The Green Plant ; Producer of Food.explanationText: Deciduous trees shed leaves in winter to survive cold.

1. The Green Plant ; Producer of Food.questionText: Q.No.45-__________ tree never shed their leaves.
1. The Green Plant ; Producer of Food.explanationText: Evergreen trees never shed all their leaves at once.

1. The Green Plant ; Producer of Food.questionText: Q.No.46-Fleshy stem of cactus store __________ in it.
1. The Green Plant ; Producer of Food.explanationText: Cactus stems store water.

1. The Green Plant ; Producer of Food.questionText: Q.No.47-Roots of this tree can go deep down, 30 mitres
1. The Green Plant ; Producer of Food.explanationText: Mesquite bush roots can grow very deep.

1. The Green Plant ; Producer of Food.questionText: Q.No.48-Which tree grows in marshy area?
1. The Green Plant ; Producer of Food.explanationText: Mangroves grow in marshy areas.

1. The Green Plant ; Producer of Food.questionText: Q.No.49-Which tree grows in marshy area?
1. The Green Plant ; Producer of Food.explanationText: Mangroves grow in marshy areas.

1. The Green Plant ; Producer of Food.questionText: Q.No.50-Plants grown in water, are called _________ plants.
1. The Green Plant ; Producer of Food.explanationText: Plants that grow in water are called aquatic plants.

1. The Green Plant ; Producer of Food.questionText: Q.No.51-Water hyacinth is a __________ plant.
1. The Green Plant ; Producer of Food.explanationText: Water hyacinth is a floating plant.

1. The Green Plant ; Producer of Food.questionText: Q.No.52-Water lily is a ________ plant.
1. The Green Plant ; Producer of Food.explanationText: Water lily is a fixed aquatic plant.

1. The Green Plant ; Producer of Food.questionText: Q.No.53-Tape grass in ________ plant.
1. The Green Plant ; Producer of Food.explanationText: Tape grass is an underwater plant.

1. The Green Plant ; Producer of Food.questionText: Q.No.54-Tape grass has narrow leaves with __________ stomata.
1. The Green Plant ; Producer of Food.explanationText: Tape grass has no stomata on its leaves.

1. The Green Plant ; Producer of Food.questionText: Q.No.55-Fungus and mushroom are __________ plants.
1. The Green Plant ; Producer of Food.explanationText: Fungi and mushrooms are non-green, not aquatic.

1. The Green Plant ; Producer of Food.questionText: Q.No.56-Which plant grow on stale bread?
1. The Green Plant ; Producer of Food.explanationText: Moulds grow on stale bread.

1. The Green Plant ; Producer of Food.questionText: Q.No.57-Pitcher plant and venus flytrap are insectivorous plant which catch __________.
1. The Green Plant ; Producer of Food.explanationText: They catch insects to get nutrition.

1. The Green Plant ; Producer of Food.questionText: Q.No.58-Plants catch insect to get _________.
1. The Green Plant ; Producer of Food.explanationText: They catch insects to get minerals (nutrients).

1. The Green Plant ; Producer of Food.questionText: Q.No.59-Poisons ivy has __________ in them.
1. The Green Plant ; Producer of Food.explanationText: Poison ivy has poison and sometimes spines.

1. The Green Plant ; Producer of Food.questionText: Q.No.60-Rose plants have __________ to protect them.
1. The Green Plant ; Producer of Food.explanationText: Roses have spines to protect themselves.

1. The Green Plant ; Producer of Food.questionText: Q.No.61-Which plants are used to make medicine antibiotic?
1. The Green Plant ; Producer of Food.explanationText: Fungi are used to make antibiotics.

1. The Green Plant ; Producer of Food.questionText: Q.No.62-Milkweed have hair on it’s seed which help in ___________ of seed.
1. The Green Plant ; Producer of Food.explanationText: Seed hairs help in dispersal.

1. The Green Plant ; Producer of Food.questionText: Q.No.63-Non – green plants are also called __________ plants.
1. The Green Plant ; Producer of Food.explanationText: Non-green plants are usually parasitic plants.

1. The Green Plant ; Producer of Food.questionText: Q.No.64-A portion of plant that grows above the ground is called ___________.
1. The Green Plant ; Producer of Food.explanationText: Shoot is the part of the plant that grows above ground.

1. The Green Plant ; Producer of Food.questionText: Q.No.65-The portion that grows below the soil is the ___________.
1. The Green Plant ; Producer of Food.explanationText: Root grows below the soil, while shoot grows above.

1. The Green Plant ; Producer of Food.questionText: Q.No.66-In a ___________ root, there is a main thick root growing from the end of stem.
1. The Green Plant ; Producer of Food.explanationText: Tap root has a main thick root from the stem.

1. The Green Plant ; Producer of Food.questionText: Q.No.67-Plant like bean, pea, balsam and mustard have ___________.
1. The Green Plant ; Producer of Food.explanationText: These plants are dicots and have tap roots.

1. The Green Plant ; Producer of Food.questionText: Q.No.68-A number of equal–sized roots that grow from the end of a stem?
1. The Green Plant ; Producer of Food.explanationText: Fibrous roots are equal-sized and arise from stem base.

1. The Green Plant ; Producer of Food.questionText: Q.No.69-Carrot and radish are example of ___________ roots.
1. The Green Plant ; Producer of Food.explanationText: Carrot and radish are tap roots storing food.

1. The Green Plant ; Producer of Food.questionText: Q.No.70-__________ fix a plant firmly to the soil.
1. The Green Plant ; Producer of Food.explanationText: Roots anchor the plant into the soil.

1. The Green Plant ; Producer of Food.questionText: Q.No.71-Type of root in grass ___________.
1. The Green Plant ; Producer of Food.explanationText: Grasses are monocots and have fibrous roots.

1. The Green Plant ; Producer of Food.questionText: Q.No.72-Which is eatable root?
1. The Green Plant ; Producer of Food.explanationText: Carrot, radish and beet root are edible roots.

1. The Green Plant ; Producer of Food.questionText: Q.No.73-The _________ has the stem, branches, leaves, buds, flowers and fruits.
1. The Green Plant ; Producer of Food.explanationText: Shoot system includes stem, leaves, buds, flowers and fruits.

1. The Green Plant ; Producer of Food.questionText: Q.No.74-Strong stem of big tree is called ___________.
1. The Green Plant ; Producer of Food.explanationText: The trunk is the strong stem of a big tree.

1. The Green Plant ; Producer of Food.questionText: Q.No.75-___________ has soft stem.
1. The Green Plant ; Producer of Food.explanationText: All these plants have soft green stems.

1. The Green Plant ; Producer of Food.questionText: Q.No.76-Pumpkin, money plant and grass have weak stem. The ___________ hold plant upright.
1. The Green Plant ; Producer of Food.explanationText: Weak stems cannot hold the plant upright.

1. The Green Plant ; Producer of Food.questionText: Q.No.77-Ginger and potato are underground __________.
1. The Green Plant ; Producer of Food.explanationText: Ginger and potato are underground stems storing food.

1. The Green Plant ; Producer of Food.questionText: Q.No.78-Which transport food and water in plants?
1. The Green Plant ; Producer of Food.explanationText: Stem transports water and food through xylem and phloem.

1. The Green Plant ; Producer of Food.questionText: Q.No.79-Which is the fastest growing woody plant?
1. The Green Plant ; Producer of Food.explanationText: Bamboo is the fastest growing woody plant.

1. The Green Plant ; Producer of Food.questionText: Q.No.80-What is called kitchen of plant?
1. The Green Plant ; Producer of Food.explanationText: Leaf makes food through photosynthesis, hence called kitchen of plant.

1. The Green Plant ; Producer of Food.questionText: Q.No.81-The flat part of a leaf is called the __________.
1. The Green Plant ; Producer of Food.explanationText: The flat green part of a leaf is called leaf blade or lamina.

1. The Green Plant ; Producer of Food.questionText: Q.No.82-The plants take in and gives out air through the ___________.
1. The Green Plant ; Producer of Food.explanationText: Stomata are tiny pores in leaves for gaseous exchange.

1. The Green Plant ; Producer of Food.questionText: Q.No.83-Leaves are mostly green in colour because of a substance called ___________.
1. The Green Plant ; Producer of Food.explanationText: Chlorophyll gives leaves their green colour.

1. The Green Plant ; Producer of Food.questionText: Q.No.84-‘Photo’ means light and synthesis means ___________.
1. The Green Plant ; Producer of Food.explanationText: Photosynthesis means ‘putting together with light’.

1. The Green Plant ; Producer of Food.questionText: Q.No.85-Plants make __________ during photosynthesis.
1. The Green Plant ; Producer of Food.explanationText: Photosynthesis produces glucose and oxygen.

1. The Green Plant ; Producer of Food.questionText: Q.No.86-Plants store extra food in their ___________.
1. The Green Plant ; Producer of Food.explanationText: Plants can store food in leaves, roots or stems.

1. The Green Plant ; Producer of Food.questionText: Q.No.87-Release of water vapour from stomata is called ___________.
1. The Green Plant ; Producer of Food.explanationText: Transpiration is the release of water vapour from leaves.

1. The Green Plant ; Producer of Food.questionText: Q.No.88-Paper, eraser, duster, we get from ___________.
1. The Green Plant ; Producer of Food.explanationText: Many products like paper, eraser, duster come from plants.

10. Force, Work and Energy.questionText: What is a push or pull on an object called?
10. Force, Work and Energy.explanationText: A push or pull on an object is called force.

10. Force, Work and Energy.questionText: Which of these is an example of force?
10. Force, Work and Energy.explanationText: Pushing a door is applying force.

10. Force, Work and Energy.questionText: Force can change the ____ of an object.
10. Force, Work and Energy.explanationText: Force can change the shape of an object.

10. Force, Work and Energy.questionText: Which force pulls objects towards the Earth?
10. Force, Work and Energy.explanationText: Gravity pulls objects towards the Earth.

10. Force, Work and Energy.questionText: What is needed to do work?
10. Force, Work and Energy.explanationText: Energy is needed to do work.

10. Force, Work and Energy.questionText: Which of these is an example of work being done?
10. Force, Work and Energy.explanationText: Carrying a bag involves work.

10. Force, Work and Energy.questionText: Which energy do we get from the Sun?
10. Force, Work and Energy.explanationText: The Sun gives us solar energy.

10. Force, Work and Energy.questionText: Moving water is used to produce?
10. Force, Work and Energy.explanationText: Moving water produces hydro energy.

10. Force, Work and Energy.questionText: Which force stops a moving object?
10. Force, Work and Energy.explanationText: Friction stops a moving object.

10. Force, Work and Energy.questionText: Which energy helps us to see?
10. Force, Work and Energy.explanationText: Light energy helps us to see.

10. Force, Work and Energy.questionText: Which type of energy helps us to cook food?
10. Force, Work and Energy.explanationText: Heat energy is used for cooking food.

10. Force, Work and Energy.questionText: Windmills are used to produce?
10. Force, Work and Energy.explanationText: Windmills produce wind energy.

10. Force, Work and Energy.questionText: Force can change the ____ of motion of an object.
10. Force, Work and Energy.explanationText: Force can change the direction of motion.

10. Force, Work and Energy.questionText: What force makes it hard to push heavy objects?
10. Force, Work and Energy.explanationText: Friction makes it hard to push heavy objects.

10. Force, Work and Energy.questionText: Which force attracts iron?
10. Force, Work and Energy.explanationText: Magnetic force attracts iron.

10. Force, Work and Energy.questionText: Energy from burning fuels is called?
10. Force, Work and Energy.explanationText: Burning fuels gives chemical energy.

10. Force, Work and Energy.questionText: Which type of energy makes machines work?
10. Force, Work and Energy.explanationText: Machines work using mechanical energy.

10. Force, Work and Energy.questionText: Which force helps us walk without slipping?
10. Force, Work and Energy.explanationText: Friction helps us walk without slipping.

10. Force, Work and Energy.questionText: Energy stored in food is?
10. Force, Work and Energy.explanationText: Food contains chemical energy.

10. Force, Work and Energy.questionText: Which energy do we hear as sound?
10. Force, Work and Energy.explanationText: We hear sound energy.

10. Force, Work and Energy.questionText: Which force makes objects fall downwards?
10. Force, Work and Energy.explanationText: Gravity makes objects fall down.

10. Force, Work and Energy.questionText: Which energy is used to run cars and buses?
10. Force, Work and Energy.explanationText: Cars and buses run on fuel energy.

10. Force, Work and Energy.questionText: Which simple machine is a seesaw?
10. Force, Work and Energy.explanationText: A seesaw works as a lever.

10. Force, Work and Energy.questionText: Work is said to be done when?

options.text: Force is applied and object moves

10. Force, Work and Energy.explanationText: Work is done only if force is applied and object moves.

10. Force, Work and Energy.questionText: Energy from moving air is called?
10. Force, Work and Energy.explanationText: Moving air gives wind energy.

10. Force, Work and Energy.questionText: A stretched rubber band has?
10. Force, Work and Energy.explanationText: A stretched rubber band stores potential energy.

10. Force, Work and Energy.questionText: Which energy is produced by vibrating objects?
10. Force, Work and Energy.explanationText: Vibrating objects produce sound energy.

10. Force, Work and Energy.questionText: Which force is used when we kick a ball?
10. Force, Work and Energy.explanationText: Kicking a ball uses muscular force.

10. Force, Work and Energy.questionText: What energy does a battery store?
10. Force, Work and Energy.explanationText: A battery stores chemical energy.

10. Force, Work and Energy.questionText: Which energy makes bulbs glow?
10. Force, Work and Energy.explanationText: Bulbs glow with electrical energy.

10. Force, Work and Energy.questionText: Which force slows down a moving car?
10. Force, Work and Energy.explanationText: Friction slows down a moving car.

10. Force, Work and Energy.questionText: Energy in moving objects is called?
10. Force, Work and Energy.explanationText: Moving objects have kinetic energy.

10. Force, Work and Energy.questionText: Which energy do we get from food?
10. Force, Work and Energy.explanationText: Food contains chemical energy.

10. Force, Work and Energy.questionText: Which simple machine helps draw water from a well?
10. Force, Work and Energy.explanationText: A pulley helps draw water from a well.

10. Force, Work and Energy.questionText: Which energy is used in loudspeakers?
10. Force, Work and Energy.explanationText: Loudspeakers work with electrical energy.

10. Force, Work and Energy.questionText: The Sun is the main source of?
10. Force, Work and Energy.explanationText: The Sun is the main source of solar energy.

10. Force, Work and Energy.questionText: Which force is used to write with a pen?
10. Force, Work and Energy.explanationText: Writing with a pen needs muscular force.

10. Force, Work and Energy.questionText: Which energy helps plants make food?
10. Force, Work and Energy.explanationText: Plants use light energy to make food.

10. Force, Work and Energy.questionText: Which energy makes an iron rod hot in fire?
10. Force, Work and Energy.explanationText: Heat energy makes an iron rod hot.

10. Force, Work and Energy.questionText: Which force keeps planets moving around the Sun?
10. Force, Work and Energy.explanationText: Gravity keeps planets moving around the Sun.

10. Force, Work and Energy.questionText: Which force helps us walk on the ground?
10. Force, Work and Energy.explanationText: Friction between feet and ground helps us walk.

10. Force, Work and Energy.questionText: Which simple machine is a knife?
10. Force, Work and Energy.explanationText: A knife works as a wedge.

10. Force, Work and Energy.questionText: Which energy is stored in coal?
10. Force, Work and Energy.explanationText: Coal stores chemical energy.

10. Force, Work and Energy.questionText: Which force stops a rolling ball on grass?
10. Force, Work and Energy.explanationText: Friction stops a rolling ball.

10. Force, Work and Energy.questionText: Which simple machine is used to lift heavy loads easily?
10. Force, Work and Energy.explanationText: Pulley helps lift heavy loads easily.

10. Force, Work and Energy.questionText: Which form of energy is used in television?
10. Force, Work and Energy.explanationText: Television runs on electrical energy.

10. Force, Work and Energy.questionText: Which force is used to cut vegetables?
10. Force, Work and Energy.explanationText: Cutting vegetables uses muscular force.

10. Force, Work and Energy.questionText: Which simple machine is a staircase?
10. Force, Work and Energy.explanationText: A staircase works like an inclined plane.

10. Force, Work and Energy.questionText: Which energy is stored in a stretched bow?
10. Force, Work and Energy.explanationText: A stretched bow has potential energy.

10. Force, Work and Energy.questionText: Which energy do we get from flowing water?
10. Force, Work and Energy.explanationText: Flowing water gives hydro energy.

10. Force, Work and Energy.questionText: Which simple machine is a bottle opener?
10. Force, Work and Energy.explanationText: A bottle opener is a type of lever.

10. Force, Work and Energy.questionText: Which energy is used by a glowing candle?
10. Force, Work and Energy.explanationText: A candle gives heat and light energy.

10. Force, Work and Energy.questionText: Which simple machine is a flagpole pulley?
10. Force, Work and Energy.explanationText: A flagpole uses a pulley to raise a flag.

10. Force, Work and Energy.questionText: Which energy helps us see objects?
10. Force, Work and Energy.explanationText: Light energy helps us see objects.

10. Force, Work and Energy.questionText: Which force makes nails stick to a magnet?
10. Force, Work and Energy.explanationText: Magnetism attracts nails.

10. Force, Work and Energy.questionText: Which form of energy cooks food in a microwave oven?
10. Force, Work and Energy.explanationText: Microwave oven uses heat energy.

10. Force, Work and Energy.questionText: Which energy moves a windmill?
10. Force, Work and Energy.explanationText: Wind energy moves a windmill.

10. Force, Work and Energy.questionText: Which simple machine is a screwdriver?
10. Force, Work and Energy.explanationText: A screwdriver is a type of screw.

10. Force, Work and Energy.questionText: Which energy comes from the Sun?
10. Force, Work and Energy.explanationText: Sunlight gives solar energy.

10. Force, Work and Energy.questionText: Which force is applied when pulling a rope?
10. Force, Work and Energy.explanationText: Pulling a rope uses pull force.

10. Force, Work and Energy.questionText: Which energy makes trains run on tracks?
10. Force, Work and Energy.explanationText: Trains run using electrical energy.

10. Force, Work and Energy.questionText: Which simple machine is used in scissors?
10. Force, Work and Energy.explanationText: Scissors are examples of levers.

10. Force, Work and Energy.questionText: Which energy is used by street lights at night?
10. Force, Work and Energy.explanationText: Street lights use electrical energy.

10. Force, Work and Energy.questionText: Which energy is stored in petroleum?
10. Force, Work and Energy.explanationText: Petroleum stores chemical energy.

10. Force, Work and Energy.questionText: Which simple machine is a wheelbarrow?
10. Force, Work and Energy.explanationText: A wheelbarrow is a lever.

10. Force, Work and Energy.questionText: Which energy makes stars shine?
10. Force, Work and Energy.explanationText: Stars shine because of heat and light energy.

10. Force, Work and Energy.questionText: Which force pulls objects towards Earth?
10. Force, Work and Energy.explanationText: Gravity pulls everything towards Earth.

10. Force, Work and Energy.questionText: Which simple machine is a spade?
10. Force, Work and Energy.explanationText: A spade works as a lever.

10. Force, Work and Energy.questionText: Which form of energy is in firecrackers?
10. Force, Work and Energy.explanationText: Firecrackers release light and sound energy.

10. Force, Work and Energy.questionText: Which energy do we get from burning wood?
10. Force, Work and Energy.explanationText: Burning wood gives heat energy.

11. The Earth and Its Neighbours.questionText: Which planet do we live on?
11. The Earth and Its Neighbours.explanationText: We live on planet Earth.

11. The Earth and Its Neighbours.questionText: Which planet is called the Red Planet?
11. The Earth and Its Neighbours.explanationText: Mars is called the Red Planet.

11. The Earth and Its Neighbours.questionText: What is the closest star to Earth?
11. The Earth and Its Neighbours.explanationText: The Sun is the closest star to Earth.

11. The Earth and Its Neighbours.questionText: Which planet is the largest in the Solar System?
11. The Earth and Its Neighbours.explanationText: Jupiter is the largest planet.

11. The Earth and Its Neighbours.questionText: Which is Earth’s only natural satellite?
11. The Earth and Its Neighbours.explanationText: The Moon is Earth’s only natural satellite.

11. The Earth and Its Neighbours.questionText: Which planet is closest to the Sun?
11. The Earth and Its Neighbours.explanationText: Mercury is the closest to the Sun.

11. The Earth and Its Neighbours.questionText: Which planet is called the Blue Planet?
11. The Earth and Its Neighbours.explanationText: Earth looks blue from space due to water.

11. The Earth and Its Neighbours.questionText: Which planet is famous for its rings?
11. The Earth and Its Neighbours.explanationText: Saturn is famous for its rings.

11. The Earth and Its Neighbours.questionText: Which planet is farthest from the Sun?
11. The Earth and Its Neighbours.explanationText: Neptune is the farthest planet.

11. The Earth and Its Neighbours.questionText: Which planet is known as Earth’s twin?
11. The Earth and Its Neighbours.explanationText: Venus is called Earth’s twin.

11. The Earth and Its Neighbours.questionText: Which planet has the Great Red Spot?
11. The Earth and Its Neighbours.explanationText: The Great Red Spot is on Jupiter.

11. The Earth and Its Neighbours.questionText: Which planet has the strongest winds?
11. The Earth and Its Neighbours.explanationText: Neptune has the strongest winds.

11. The Earth and Its Neighbours.questionText: How many planets are there in the Solar System?
11. The Earth and Its Neighbours.explanationText: There are 8 planets in the Solar System.

11. The Earth and Its Neighbours.questionText: Which planet is second from the Sun?
11. The Earth and Its Neighbours.explanationText: Venus is the second planet from the Sun.

11. The Earth and Its Neighbours.questionText: What does Earth’s axis cause?
11. The Earth and Its Neighbours.explanationText: Earth’s rotation causes day and night.

11. The Earth and Its Neighbours.questionText: What does Earth’s revolution around the Sun cause?
11. The Earth and Its Neighbours.explanationText: Revolution causes seasons.

11. The Earth and Its Neighbours.questionText: Which is the smallest planet?
11. The Earth and Its Neighbours.explanationText: Mercury is the smallest planet.

11. The Earth and Its Neighbours.questionText: Which is the hottest planet?
11. The Earth and Its Neighbours.explanationText: Venus is the hottest planet.

11. The Earth and Its Neighbours.questionText: Which planet is tilted on its side?
11. The Earth and Its Neighbours.explanationText: Uranus is tilted on its side.

11. The Earth and Its Neighbours.questionText: What shape is the Earth?
11. The Earth and Its Neighbours.explanationText: Earth is spherical in shape.

11. The Earth and Its Neighbours.questionText: Which force keeps planets in orbit around the Sun?
11. The Earth and Its Neighbours.explanationText: Gravity keeps planets in orbit.

11. The Earth and Its Neighbours.questionText: What is the path of Earth around the Sun called?
11. The Earth and Its Neighbours.explanationText: Earth moves in an orbit around the Sun.

11. The Earth and Its Neighbours.questionText: Which planet is called the “Morning Star”?
11. The Earth and Its Neighbours.explanationText: Venus is called the Morning Star.

11. The Earth and Its Neighbours.questionText: Which planet is also called the “Evening Star”?
11. The Earth and Its Neighbours.explanationText: Venus is called the Evening Star.

11. The Earth and Its Neighbours.questionText: Which planet has life?
11. The Earth and Its Neighbours.explanationText: Earth supports life.

11. The Earth and Its Neighbours.questionText: Which planet has the longest day?
11. The Earth and Its Neighbours.explanationText: Venus has the longest day.

11. The Earth and Its Neighbours.questionText: Which planet is called the Gas Giant?
11. The Earth and Its Neighbours.explanationText: Jupiter is a gas giant.

11. The Earth and Its Neighbours.questionText: Which planet is called the Ice Giant?
11. The Earth and Its Neighbours.explanationText: Uranus is called an ice giant.

11. The Earth and Its Neighbours.questionText: Which planet has 14 known moons?
11. The Earth and Its Neighbours.explanationText: Neptune has 14 known moons.

11. The Earth and Its Neighbours.questionText: Which planet is called the "Dwarf Planet"?
11. The Earth and Its Neighbours.explanationText: Pluto is a dwarf planet.

11. The Earth and Its Neighbours.questionText: What causes phases of the Moon?
11. The Earth and Its Neighbours.explanationText: Moon’s revolution around Earth causes phases.

11. The Earth and Its Neighbours.questionText: What causes solar eclipse?
11. The Earth and Its Neighbours.explanationText: Solar eclipse happens when Moon comes between Earth and Sun.

11. The Earth and Its Neighbours.questionText: What causes lunar eclipse?
11. The Earth and Its Neighbours.explanationText: Lunar eclipse happens when Earth comes between Sun and Moon.

11. The Earth and Its Neighbours.questionText: Which planet has a day almost equal to Earth’s day?
11. The Earth and Its Neighbours.explanationText: Mars has a day length similar to Earth.

11. The Earth and Its Neighbours.questionText: Which planet has a year shortest among all?
11. The Earth and Its Neighbours.explanationText: Mercury has the shortest year.

11. The Earth and Its Neighbours.questionText: Which planet takes the longest to orbit the Sun?
11. The Earth and Its Neighbours.explanationText: Neptune takes the longest time.

11. The Earth and Its Neighbours.questionText: Which planet has the maximum moons?
11. The Earth and Its Neighbours.explanationText: Saturn has the most moons.

11. The Earth and Its Neighbours.questionText: Which gas is most found in Sun?
11. The Earth and Its Neighbours.explanationText: The Sun is mostly hydrogen.

11. The Earth and Its Neighbours.questionText: Which planet has the thickest atmosphere?
11. The Earth and Its Neighbours.explanationText: Venus has the thickest atmosphere.

11. The Earth and Its Neighbours.questionText: Which planet has Olympus Mons, the largest volcano?
11. The Earth and Its Neighbours.explanationText: Mars has Olympus Mons volcano.

11. The Earth and Its Neighbours.questionText: What is the shape of the Moon’s orbit around Earth?
11. The Earth and Its Neighbours.explanationText: Moon moves around Earth in an oval orbit.

11. The Earth and Its Neighbours.questionText: What protects Earth from Sun’s harmful rays?
11. The Earth and Its Neighbours.explanationText: Ozone layer protects Earth.

11. The Earth and Its Neighbours.questionText: Which side of the Moon always faces Earth?
11. The Earth and Its Neighbours.explanationText: Only the front side of Moon faces Earth.

11. The Earth and Its Neighbours.questionText: Which planet is famous for its beautiful blue color?
11. The Earth and Its Neighbours.explanationText: Neptune is blue in color.

11. The Earth and Its Neighbours.questionText: Which planet is famous for having rings besides Saturn?
11. The Earth and Its Neighbours.explanationText: Uranus, Jupiter, and Neptune also have rings.

11. The Earth and Its Neighbours.questionText: Which is the brightest object in night sky?
11. The Earth and Its Neighbours.explanationText: Moon is the brightest in the night sky.

11. The Earth and Its Neighbours.questionText: Which is the brightest planet in the night sky?
11. The Earth and Its Neighbours.explanationText: Venus is the brightest planet.

11. The Earth and Its Neighbours.questionText: What is the galaxy name in which Earth lies?
11. The Earth and Its Neighbours.explanationText: Earth is in Milky Way galaxy.

11. The Earth and Its Neighbours.questionText: Which planet is called the “Jewel of the Solar System”?
11. The Earth and Its Neighbours.explanationText: Saturn is called Jewel of Solar System.

11. The Earth and Its Neighbours.questionText: Which planet is sometimes called the “Evening Lantern”?
11. The Earth and Its Neighbours.explanationText: Venus is called Evening Lantern.

12. Air, Water and Weather.questionText: Which gas is most abundant in air?
12. Air, Water and Weather.explanationText: Nitrogen makes up about 78% of air.

12. Air, Water and Weather.questionText: Which gas in air is essential for breathing?
12. Air, Water and Weather.explanationText: We breathe oxygen to stay alive.

12. Air, Water and Weather.questionText: Which gas in air is used by plants to make food?
12. Air, Water and Weather.explanationText: Plants use carbon dioxide for photosynthesis.

12. Air, Water and Weather.questionText: Which layer of atmosphere contains ozone?
12. Air, Water and Weather.explanationText: Ozone layer is in the stratosphere.

12. Air, Water and Weather.questionText: What is the process of changing water into vapor called?
12. Air, Water and Weather.explanationText: Heat changes water into vapor by evaporation.

12. Air, Water and Weather.questionText: What is the process of water vapor turning into clouds?
12. Air, Water and Weather.explanationText: Condensation changes vapor into tiny droplets.

12. Air, Water and Weather.questionText: Which form of water falls as snow?
Which form of water is rain?
Which form of water is steam?
What is the main source of water on Earth?
12. Air, Water and Weather.explanationText: Oceans are the main source of water.

12. Air, Water and Weather.questionText: What is the purest form of natural water?
Which water is fit for drinking after boiling?
12. Air, Water and Weather.explanationText: Boiled tap water is safe for drinking.

12. Air, Water and Weather.questionText: What is used to kill germs in drinking water?
Which gas in air is used in burning?
Which instrument measures rainfall?
Which instrument measures air pressure?
Which instrument measures temperature?
Which instrument measures humidity?
Which layer of atmosphere is closest to Earth?
Which form of water do we drink?
Clouds are formed due to?
Dew is formed by?
12. Air, Water and Weather.explanationText: Dew forms when vapor condenses on cold surfaces.

12. Air, Water and Weather.questionText: Fog is?
12. Air, Water and Weather.explanationText: Fog is made of tiny water droplets.

12. Air, Water and Weather.questionText: Which gas in air makes food spoil?
What is the main cause of winds?
Which gas in air makes lime water milky?
12. Air, Water and Weather.explanationText: Carbon dioxide makes lime water milky.

12. Air, Water and Weather.questionText: What is the main source of energy for water cycle?
12. Air, Water and Weather.explanationText: The Sun drives the water cycle.

12. Air, Water and Weather.questionText: Which clouds are white and fluffy?
12. Air, Water and Weather.explanationText: Cumulus clouds are white and fluffy.

12. Air, Water and Weather.questionText: Which clouds bring rain?
What is the freezing point of water?
What is the boiling point of water?
Which property of air helps in flying kites?
Which property of air helps balloons rise?
12. Air, Water and Weather.explanationText: Hot air rises and makes balloons rise.

12. Air, Water and Weather.questionText: Which gas in air is harmful when in excess?
Which type of water is salty?
Which water is best for irrigation?
12. Air, Water and Weather.explanationText: River water is best for irrigation.

12. Air, Water and Weather.questionText: Which form of precipitation is soft ice?
Which form of precipitation is hard ice?
Which water is not fit for drinking?
12. Air, Water and Weather.explanationText: Sea water is salty, not fit for drinking.

12. Air, Water and Weather.questionText: Which season gets the most rain?
Which process makes clothes dry in the sun?
Which process forms icicles in winter?
Which layer of atmosphere is used for radio waves?
Which gas protects us from UV rays?
12. Air, Water and Weather.explanationText: Ozone protects us from UV rays.

12. Air, Water and Weather.questionText: Which gas do animals release during breathing?
Which gas do plants release during photosynthesis?
What is moving air called?
A very strong wind is called?
12. Air, Water and Weather.explanationText: A storm is a very strong wind.

12. Air, Water and Weather.questionText: Which season has the hottest days?
Which season is the coldest?

13. Soil.questionText: What is the uppermost layer of the Earth called?
13. Soil.explanationText: The uppermost layer of Earth is soil.

13. Soil.questionText: Which type of soil holds the most water?
13. Soil.explanationText: Clayey soil holds water as it has very small particles.

13. Soil.questionText: Which type of soil is best for growing crops?
13. Soil.explanationText: Loamy soil is a mixture of sand, clay, and humus; best for crops.

13. Soil.questionText: What gives soil its dark color?
13. Soil.explanationText: Humus gives soil its dark color.

13. Soil.questionText: Soil is formed from?
13. Soil.explanationText: Soil forms when rocks break down over time.

13. Soil.questionText: Which soil has large particles?
13. Soil.explanationText: Sandy soil has large particles and feels gritty.

13. Soil.questionText: Which soil cracks when it dries?
13. Soil.explanationText: Clayey soil cracks on drying.

13. Soil.questionText: Which soil is called “farmer’s friend”?
13. Soil.explanationText: Loamy soil is ideal for farming.

13. Soil.questionText: What is humus made of?
13. Soil.explanationText: Humus is formed from decayed plants and animals.

13. Soil.questionText: Which soil drains water quickly?
13. Soil.explanationText: Sandy soil drains water quickly.

13. Soil.questionText: What protects soil from being blown away by wind?
13. Soil.explanationText: Plants hold soil and prevent erosion.

13. Soil.questionText: Which soil is sticky when wet?
13. Soil.explanationText: Clayey soil is sticky when wet.

13. Soil.questionText: Which soil is common in deserts?
13. Soil.explanationText: Sandy soil is found in deserts.

13. Soil.questionText: Which soil is found near rivers?
13. Soil.explanationText: Alluvial soil is found near rivers.

13. Soil.questionText: Soil erosion is caused by?
13. Soil.explanationText: Wind and rain wash away soil.

13. Soil.questionText: Which soil is good for cotton plants?
13. Soil.explanationText: Black soil is good for cotton.

13. Soil.questionText: Which soil is rich in humus?
13. Soil.explanationText: Loamy soil is rich in humus.

13. Soil.questionText: What is soil conservation?
13. Soil.explanationText: Soil conservation means protecting soil from erosion.

13. Soil.questionText: Which layer of soil has maximum humus?
13. Soil.explanationText: Topsoil is rich in humus.

13. Soil.questionText: What is the bottom-most layer of soil called?
13. Soil.explanationText: Bedrock is the bottom-most layer.

13. Soil.questionText: Which soil is best for making pots?
13. Soil.explanationText: Clayey soil is used to make pots.

13. Soil.questionText: Which soil is light and easy to plough?
13. Soil.explanationText: Sandy soil is light and easy to plough.

13. Soil.questionText: Which soil holds air well?
13. Soil.explanationText: Sandy soil holds air in its spaces.

13. Soil.questionText: The process of decayed plants mixing with soil is called?
13. Soil.explanationText: Composting makes humus.

13. Soil.questionText: Which soil is rich in iron?
13. Soil.explanationText: Red soil contains iron.

13. Soil.questionText: Which type of soil is fertile in plains?
13. Soil.explanationText: Plains have fertile alluvial soil.

13. Soil.questionText: Soil becomes less fertile due to?
13. Soil.explanationText: Erosion reduces fertility.

13. Soil.questionText: What is added to soil to increase fertility?
13. Soil.explanationText: Fertilizers increase soil fertility.

13. Soil.questionText: Which soil is formed by volcanoes?
13. Soil.explanationText: Black soil is formed by lava.

13. Soil.questionText: What do earthworms do to soil?
13. Soil.explanationText: Earthworms improve soil fertility.

13. Soil.questionText: Which soil needs less water for crops?
13. Soil.explanationText: Sandy soil crops need less water.

13. Soil.questionText: Which soil is common in hilly areas?
13. Soil.explanationText: Red soil is found in hilly areas.

13. Soil.questionText: Soil erosion can be prevented by?
13. Soil.explanationText: Plants prevent soil erosion.

13. Soil.questionText: Which soil supports rice cultivation?
13. Soil.explanationText: Rice grows well in clayey soil.

13. Soil.questionText: Which soil is most suitable for wheat?
13. Soil.explanationText: Loamy soil is best for wheat.

13. Soil.questionText: Which soil is least fertile?
13. Soil.explanationText: Sandy soil is least fertile.

13. Soil.questionText: What is subsoil rich in?
13. Soil.explanationText: Subsoil has minerals.

13. Soil.questionText: Soil provides what to plants?
13. Soil.explanationText: Soil gives plants water and minerals.

13. Soil.questionText: Which soil supports sugarcane cultivation?
13. Soil.explanationText: Black soil supports sugarcane.

13. Soil.questionText: Which soil supports cotton and tobacco?
13. Soil.explanationText: Black soil supports cotton and tobacco.

13. Soil.questionText: What is the study of soil called?
13. Soil.explanationText: The study of soil is called Pedology.

13. Soil.questionText: Which soil is best for gardening?
13. Soil.explanationText: Loamy soil is best for gardening.

13. Soil.questionText: Which layer is beneath topsoil?
13. Soil.explanationText: Subsoil lies beneath topsoil.

13. Soil.questionText: Which soil holds water but drains slowly?
13. Soil.explanationText: Clayey soil holds water but drains slowly.

13. Soil.questionText: What is soil pollution?
13. Soil.explanationText: Waste and chemicals cause soil pollution.

13. Soil.questionText: Which crops grow well in alluvial soil?
13. Soil.explanationText: Rice and wheat grow well in alluvial soil.

13. Soil.questionText: Which soil is formed near coasts?
13. Soil.explanationText: Sandy soil is common near coasts.

13. Soil.questionText: Which soil is yellow in color?
13. Soil.explanationText: Yellow soil is found in some regions.

13. Soil.questionText: Which factor is most important in soil formation?
13. Soil.explanationText: Weathering of rocks forms soil.

13. Soil.questionText: Which is the most fertile soil of India?
13. Soil.explanationText: Alluvial soil is most fertile.

13. Soil.questionText: Which soil is common in deserts of Rajasthan?
13. Soil.explanationText: Sandy soil is common in deserts.

14. Resources in Our Daily Life.questionText: Which of these is a natural resource?
Which of these is a human-made resource?
Which resource do we need for breathing?
Which is the main source of energy for life on Earth?
14. Resources in Our Daily Life.explanationText: The Sun is the main source of energy.

14. Resources in Our Daily Life.questionText: Which of these is a renewable resource?
Which of these is a non-renewable resource?
What type of resource is water?
Which is an example of human resource?
14. Resources in Our Daily Life.explanationText: A doctor is a human resource.

14. Resources in Our Daily Life.questionText: Which natural resource covers most of the Earth’s surface?
14. Resources in Our Daily Life.explanationText: Water covers most of Earth’s surface.

14. Resources in Our Daily Life.questionText: Which resource is used to make paper?
Which gas is most important for breathing?
Which of these is used for cooking in villages?
14. Resources in Our Daily Life.explanationText: Wood is used as fuel in villages.

14. Resources in Our Daily Life.questionText: Which of these is a mineral resource?
What type of resource is sunlight?
Which is used to generate electricity in dams?
14. Resources in Our Daily Life.explanationText: Water is used in dams for electricity.

14. Resources in Our Daily Life.questionText: Which of these is a living resource?
Which is the best example of conserving resources?
Which is not a natural resource?
Which resource is used in pencils?
Which of these is a fossil fuel?
What type of resource is petroleum?
Which resource gives us fruits and vegetables?
14. Resources in Our Daily Life.explanationText: Forests give us fruits and vegetables.

14. Resources in Our Daily Life.questionText: Which of these is a resource from animals?
Which is a metallic resource?
Which of these is a non-metallic resource?
Which resource is needed for farming?
Which of these is made from petroleum?
Which of these helps in transport?
Which is an energy resource?
Which resource is used in glass making?
14. Resources in Our Daily Life.explanationText: Sand is used to make glass.

14. Resources in Our Daily Life.questionText: Which resource is essential for drinking?
What type of resource is cotton?
Which of these is an example of renewable energy?
Which natural resource is used to make salt?
Which human resource works in hospitals?
Which of these is not an energy resource?
14. Resources in Our Daily Life.explanationText: Iron is not an energy resource.

14. Resources in Our Daily Life.questionText: Which of these is obtained from animals?
Which of these is a water resource?
Which resource helps in making jewelry?
Which is the most important resource for plants?
Which of these is a human-made resource?
Which is the ultimate source of all energy?
14. Resources in Our Daily Life.explanationText: The Sun is the ultimate energy source.

14. Resources in Our Daily Life.questionText: Which gas is used by plants for photosynthesis?
Which is the cleanest form of energy?
Which mineral is used in pencils?
Which is a recyclable resource?
Which of these is a resource from the sea?
14. Resources in Our Daily Life.explanationText: Salt is obtained from sea water.

14. Resources in Our Daily Life.questionText: Which of these is used to make clothes?
14. Resources in Our Daily Life.explanationText: Cotton is used to make clothes.

14. Resources in Our Daily Life.questionText: Which human-made resource helps in communication?
Which is the main fuel used in kitchens today?
14. Resources in Our Daily Life.explanationText: LPG is the main kitchen fuel.

14. Resources in Our Daily Life.questionText: Which is a precious natural resource?

2. Plant Habitats.questionText: Which of these animals is a herbivore?
2. Plant Habitats.explanationText: Cow is a herbivore because it eats only plants.

2. Plant Habitats.questionText: What is the natural home of an animal called?
2. Plant Habitats.explanationText: An animal's natural home is called its habitat.

2. Plant Habitats.questionText: A baby butterfly is called a:
2. Plant Habitats.explanationText: A baby butterfly is called a caterpillar.

2. Plant Habitats.questionText: Which animal breathes through gills?
2. Plant Habitats.explanationText: Fish breathe through gills.

2. Plant Habitats.questionText: The process where an animal sheds its old skin is called:
2. Plant Habitats.explanationText: Shedding old skin is called moulting.

2. Plant Habitats.questionText: Which of these animals is an omnivore?
2. Plant Habitats.explanationText: Bears eat both plants and animals, so they are omnivores.

2. Plant Habitats.questionText: Which of these animals lays eggs?
2. Plant Habitats.explanationText: Hens lay eggs.

2. Plant Habitats.questionText: An animal that lives both on land and in water is called a(n):
2. Plant Habitats.explanationText: Amphibians live both on land and in water.

2. Plant Habitats.questionText: A long winter sleep to protect from the cold is called:
2. Plant Habitats.explanationText: A long winter sleep is called hibernation.

2. Plant Habitats.questionText: Which animal undergoes a four-stage life cycle: egg, larva, pupa, and adult?
2. Plant Habitats.explanationText: Butterflies undergo complete metamorphosis with 4 stages.

2. Plant Habitats.questionText: What is a baby rabbit called?
2. Plant Habitats.explanationText: A baby rabbit is called a kit.

2. Plant Habitats.questionText: The cocoon stage in a butterfly's life cycle is also known as the:
2. Plant Habitats.explanationText: The cocoon stage is the pupa stage.

2. Plant Habitats.questionText: What is a group of frog eggs called?
2. Plant Habitats.explanationText: A group of frog eggs is called spawn.

2. Plant Habitats.questionText: Which animal feeds its babies milk?
2. Plant Habitats.explanationText: Mammals feed their babies milk.

2. Plant Habitats.questionText: How does a hen care for its young?

options.text: It carries them in a pouch.
It keeps its eggs warm until they hatch.
It lets them find their own food.

2. Plant Habitats.explanationText: A hen keeps its eggs warm until they hatch.

2. Plant Habitats.questionText: A baby goat is called a:
2. Plant Habitats.explanationText: A baby goat is called a kid.

2. Plant Habitats.questionText: Which is the fastest land animal?
2. Plant Habitats.explanationText: Cheetah is the fastest land animal.

2. Plant Habitats.questionText: The fur of a polar bear helps it stay warm in cold weather. This is an example of:
2. Plant Habitats.explanationText: Thick fur is an adaptation to survive cold.

2. Plant Habitats.questionText: The chameleon is known for its ability to change its skin color to match its surroundings. This is called:
2. Plant Habitats.explanationText: Changing color to blend in is called camouflage.

2. Plant Habitats.questionText: Which animal has a thick layer of fat called blubber to keep it warm?
2. Plant Habitats.explanationText: Walrus has blubber to stay warm.

3. Reproduction in Animals.questionText: What is reproduction?
3. Reproduction in Animals.explanationText: Reproduction means making young ones.

3. Reproduction in Animals.questionText: Why do animals reproduce?
3. Reproduction in Animals.explanationText: Reproduction helps the species continue.

3. Reproduction in Animals.questionText: Which of these animals lay eggs?
3. Reproduction in Animals.explanationText: Hens are oviparous (egg-laying).

3. Reproduction in Animals.questionText: Which of these animals give birth to babies?
3. Reproduction in Animals.explanationText: Cows are mammals and give birth.

3. Reproduction in Animals.questionText: Animals that give birth to young ones are called:
3. Reproduction in Animals.explanationText: Viviparous animals give birth to babies.

3. Reproduction in Animals.questionText: Animals that lay eggs are called:
3. Reproduction in Animals.explanationText: Oviparous animals reproduce by laying eggs.

3. Reproduction in Animals.questionText: Which of these is an example of a viviparous animal?
3. Reproduction in Animals.explanationText: Dogs give birth to puppies.

3. Reproduction in Animals.questionText: Which of these is an example of an oviparous animal?
3. Reproduction in Animals.explanationText: Hens lay eggs.

3. Reproduction in Animals.questionText: The process of development of a baby inside the mother’s body is called:
3. Reproduction in Animals.explanationText: Pregnancy is baby development inside the mother.

3. Reproduction in Animals.questionText: Which animal lays the largest egg?
3. Reproduction in Animals.explanationText: Ostrich eggs are the largest among birds.

3. Reproduction in Animals.questionText: Which of these animals lays eggs in water?
3. Reproduction in Animals.explanationText: Frogs lay eggs in water.

3. Reproduction in Animals.questionText: Which part of the egg provides food to the growing chick?
3. Reproduction in Animals.explanationText: The yolk provides nourishment.

3. Reproduction in Animals.questionText: The hard outer covering of an egg is called:
3. Reproduction in Animals.explanationText: The shell protects the embryo.

3. Reproduction in Animals.questionText: Which of these animals lays hundreds of eggs at a time?
3. Reproduction in Animals.explanationText: Frogs lay many eggs at once.

3. Reproduction in Animals.questionText: A hen takes care of her eggs by:

options.text: Sitting on them to keep them warm

3. Reproduction in Animals.explanationText: This is called incubation.

3. Reproduction in Animals.questionText: Which of these animals lay eggs but also live on land and water?
3. Reproduction in Animals.explanationText: Frogs are amphibians.

3. Reproduction in Animals.questionText: Which insect lays eggs?
3. Reproduction in Animals.explanationText: Insects reproduce by laying eggs.

3. Reproduction in Animals.questionText: Caterpillar comes out from the:
3. Reproduction in Animals.explanationText: Butterfly eggs hatch into caterpillars.

3. Reproduction in Animals.questionText: Which of these is an egg-laying mammal?
3. Reproduction in Animals.explanationText: Platypus is a monotreme that lays eggs.

3. Reproduction in Animals.questionText: Which stage comes after egg in the life cycle of a frog?
3. Reproduction in Animals.explanationText: A frog egg hatches into a tadpole.

3. Reproduction in Animals.questionText: All mammals:
3. Reproduction in Animals.explanationText: Mammals usually give birth (few exceptions lay eggs).

3. Reproduction in Animals.questionText: Which of these is NOT a mammal?
3. Reproduction in Animals.explanationText: Snakes are reptiles.

3. Reproduction in Animals.questionText: Young ones of a cow are called:
3. Reproduction in Animals.explanationText: A cow’s baby is a calf.

3. Reproduction in Animals.questionText: Young ones of a dog are called:
3. Reproduction in Animals.explanationText: A dog’s baby is a puppy.

3. Reproduction in Animals.questionText: Which mammal lives in water but gives birth to babies?
3. Reproduction in Animals.explanationText: Whales are mammals and give birth.

3. Reproduction in Animals.questionText: Which of these mammals can fly?
3. Reproduction in Animals.explanationText: Bats are flying mammals.

3. Reproduction in Animals.questionText: Which of these mammals lay eggs?
3. Reproduction in Animals.explanationText: Monotremes like platypus lay eggs.

3. Reproduction in Animals.questionText: Human babies grow inside:
3. Reproduction in Animals.explanationText: Humans are viviparous.

3. Reproduction in Animals.questionText: Which mammal carries its baby in a pouch?
3. Reproduction in Animals.explanationText: Kangaroos are marsupials with pouches.

3. Reproduction in Animals.questionText: Dolphins reproduce by:

options.text: Laying thousands of eggs in water

3. Reproduction in Animals.explanationText: Dolphins are mammals.

3. Reproduction in Animals.questionText: The young one of a butterfly is called:
3. Reproduction in Animals.explanationText: A caterpillar is the larva of a butterfly.

3. Reproduction in Animals.questionText: The process of change from egg → caterpillar → pupa → butterfly is called:
3. Reproduction in Animals.explanationText: A big change in body form is metamorphosis.

3. Reproduction in Animals.questionText: Which animal’s life cycle includes tadpole?
3. Reproduction in Animals.explanationText: Frogs have a tadpole stage.

3. Reproduction in Animals.questionText: Which animal guards its eggs carefully?
3. Reproduction in Animals.explanationText: Crocodiles protect their nests.

3. Reproduction in Animals.questionText: Which part of the egg protects the chick?
3. Reproduction in Animals.explanationText: The shell is the hard outer protection.

3. Reproduction in Animals.questionText: The white part of the egg is called:
3. Reproduction in Animals.explanationText: Albumin is egg white.

3. Reproduction in Animals.questionText: Which insect undergoes complete metamorphosis?
3. Reproduction in Animals.explanationText: Butterflies change from egg to larva to pupa to adult.

3. Reproduction in Animals.questionText: Which stage of a butterfly’s life cycle is also called cocoon?
3. Reproduction in Animals.explanationText: The pupa is often called a cocoon/chrysalis.

3. Reproduction in Animals.questionText: Which of these animals live on land and in water (amphibian)?
3. Reproduction in Animals.explanationText: Frogs live both on land and in water.

3. Reproduction in Animals.questionText: Which animal makes a nest before laying eggs?
3. Reproduction in Animals.explanationText: Birds like hens make nests to lay eggs.

3. Reproduction in Animals.questionText: Which is common between birds and reptiles?
3. Reproduction in Animals.explanationText: Birds and many reptiles are egg-layers.

3. Reproduction in Animals.questionText: Which of these does NOT reproduce by laying eggs?
3. Reproduction in Animals.explanationText: Cats give birth to kittens.

3. Reproduction in Animals.questionText: Which of these protects the embryo inside the egg?
3. Reproduction in Animals.explanationText: The shell is the hard protective covering.

3. Reproduction in Animals.questionText: A tadpole breathes through:
3. Reproduction in Animals.explanationText: Tadpoles use gills like fish.

3. Reproduction in Animals.questionText: Which bird lays eggs but cannot fly?
3. Reproduction in Animals.explanationText: Ostriches are flightless birds.

3. Reproduction in Animals.questionText: Which animal is called a marsupial because it carries its baby in a pouch?
3. Reproduction in Animals.explanationText: Marsupials keep babies in a pouch.

3. Reproduction in Animals.questionText: Which animal produces milk for its babies?
3. Reproduction in Animals.explanationText: Mammals feed milk to their young.

3. Reproduction in Animals.questionText: Which animal’s young one is called a joey?
3. Reproduction in Animals.explanationText: A baby kangaroo is called a joey.

3. Reproduction in Animals.questionText: Which animal lays leathery eggs instead of hard-shelled eggs?
3. Reproduction in Animals.explanationText: Many reptile eggs are leathery.

3. Reproduction in Animals.questionText: Which of these is an aquatic mammal?
3. Reproduction in Animals.explanationText: Whales live in water and are mammals.

4. Adaptation in Animals.questionText: What is adaptation in animals?
4. Adaptation in Animals.explanationText: Adaptation helps animals live in their environment.

4. Adaptation in Animals.questionText: Why do animals adapt?
4. Adaptation in Animals.explanationText: Adaptations help animals live safely in their surroundings.

4. Adaptation in Animals.questionText: Which is an example of adaptation?
4. Adaptation in Animals.explanationText: Polar bears’ thick fur keeps them warm in cold places.

4. Adaptation in Animals.questionText: Animals living in deserts usually:
4. Adaptation in Animals.explanationText: Desert animals like camels store water.

4. Adaptation in Animals.questionText: Which of these helps fish to swim?
4. Adaptation in Animals.explanationText: Fins help fish move in water.

4. Adaptation in Animals.questionText: Which animals blend with surroundings for protection?
4. Adaptation in Animals.explanationText: Camouflage helps animals hide from enemies.

4. Adaptation in Animals.questionText: Animals living in cold places have:
4. Adaptation in Animals.explanationText: Thick fur protects from cold.

4. Adaptation in Animals.questionText: Which animal sleeps in winter to survive cold?
4. Adaptation in Animals.explanationText: Bears hibernate during winter.

4. Adaptation in Animals.questionText: What do desert animals avoid doing in the day?
4. Adaptation in Animals.explanationText: Desert animals stay in shade in daytime heat.

4. Adaptation in Animals.questionText: Which adaptation helps birds fly?
4. Adaptation in Animals.explanationText: Hollow bones make birds light to fly.

4. Adaptation in Animals.questionText: Which animal has padded feet to walk on sand?
4. Adaptation in Animals.explanationText: Camel’s padded feet help it walk on hot sand.

4. Adaptation in Animals.questionText: Why do lions have sharp claws?
4. Adaptation in Animals.explanationText: Sharp claws help lions hunt animals.

4. Adaptation in Animals.questionText: Which animal has a long trunk to eat and drink water?
4. Adaptation in Animals.explanationText: Elephants use trunks to eat, drink, and smell.

4. Adaptation in Animals.questionText: Which feature helps deer to escape enemies?
4. Adaptation in Animals.explanationText: Deer run fast to escape predators.

4. Adaptation in Animals.questionText: Which animal has stripes on its body for camouflage?
4. Adaptation in Animals.explanationText: Stripes help zebras hide in grasslands.

4. Adaptation in Animals.questionText: Which desert animal stores fat in its hump?
4. Adaptation in Animals.explanationText: Camels store fat in their humps for energy.

4. Adaptation in Animals.questionText: Why do elephants have large ears?

options.text: To fan themselves and keep cool

4. Adaptation in Animals.explanationText: Elephants use ears to control body temperature.

4. Adaptation in Animals.questionText: Which feature helps porcupine protect itself?
4. Adaptation in Animals.explanationText: Porcupines use sharp quills for defense.

4. Adaptation in Animals.questionText: Which desert reptile can change its body color?
4. Adaptation in Animals.explanationText: Chameleons change color to hide.

4. Adaptation in Animals.questionText: Which animal digs burrows to escape heat?
4. Adaptation in Animals.explanationText: Rabbits live in burrows to stay safe and cool.

4. Adaptation in Animals.questionText: Which organ helps fish breathe in water?
4. Adaptation in Animals.explanationText: Gills help fish take oxygen from water.

4. Adaptation in Animals.questionText: Whales and dolphins breathe through:
4. Adaptation in Animals.explanationText: Whales use blowholes to breathe air.

4. Adaptation in Animals.questionText: Which body shape helps fish swim easily?
4. Adaptation in Animals.explanationText: Streamlined shape reduces water resistance.

4. Adaptation in Animals.questionText: Why do ducks have webbed feet?
4. Adaptation in Animals.explanationText: Webbed feet act like paddles.

4. Adaptation in Animals.questionText: Which animal has flippers instead of legs?
4. Adaptation in Animals.explanationText: Seals use flippers to swim in water.

4. Adaptation in Animals.questionText: Which aquatic mammal gives birth to babies?
4. Adaptation in Animals.explanationText: Whales are mammals and give birth.

4. Adaptation in Animals.questionText: Which fish has an electric shock for defense?
4. Adaptation in Animals.explanationText: Electric eels generate electricity to protect themselves.

4. Adaptation in Animals.questionText: Which adaptation helps penguins swim?
4. Adaptation in Animals.explanationText: Penguins use wings like flippers for swimming.

4. Adaptation in Animals.questionText: Which aquatic animal has ink to escape enemies?
4. Adaptation in Animals.explanationText: Octopus releases ink cloud to hide.

4. Adaptation in Animals.questionText: Why do polar bears have white fur?
4. Adaptation in Animals.explanationText: White fur camouflages polar bears in ice.

4. Adaptation in Animals.questionText: Which feature helps birds fly?
4. Adaptation in Animals.explanationText: Wings and hollow bones make birds light to fly.

4. Adaptation in Animals.questionText: Which bird cannot fly but can run fast?
4. Adaptation in Animals.explanationText: Ostriches are flightless birds but run fast.

4. Adaptation in Animals.questionText: Why do birds have beaks?
4. Adaptation in Animals.explanationText: Different birds have beaks for eating different foods.

4. Adaptation in Animals.questionText: Which bird has long beak to catch fish?
4. Adaptation in Animals.explanationText: Kingfishers use long beaks to catch fish.

4. Adaptation in Animals.questionText: Which bird has strong claws called talons?
4. Adaptation in Animals.explanationText: Eagles use talons to catch prey.

4. Adaptation in Animals.questionText: Which bird migrates long distances in winter?
4. Adaptation in Animals.explanationText: Siberian cranes migrate to warmer regions.

4. Adaptation in Animals.questionText: Which adaptation helps bats fly at night?
4. Adaptation in Animals.explanationText: Bats use sound waves to find objects in dark.

4. Adaptation in Animals.questionText: Which bird can turn its head almost fully?
4. Adaptation in Animals.explanationText: Owls can rotate head nearly 270 degrees.

4. Adaptation in Animals.questionText: Why do migratory birds travel long distances?
4. Adaptation in Animals.explanationText: Birds migrate for food and better climate.

4. Adaptation in Animals.questionText: Which bird has nostrils on top of its beak for swimming?
4. Adaptation in Animals.explanationText: Duck’s beak has holes for breathing while swimming.

4. Adaptation in Animals.questionText: Which animal stores food in cheek pouches?
4. Adaptation in Animals.explanationText: Squirrels store food in cheek pouches.

4. Adaptation in Animals.questionText: Which animal can survive without water for days?
4. Adaptation in Animals.explanationText: Camels can survive long without water.

4. Adaptation in Animals.questionText: Which animal uses poison to protect itself?
4. Adaptation in Animals.explanationText: Snakes use venom as defense.

4. Adaptation in Animals.questionText: Which insect has colorful wings for protection?
4. Adaptation in Animals.explanationText: Butterflies use bright colors to scare enemies.

4. Adaptation in Animals.questionText: Which animal rolls into a ball for defense?
4. Adaptation in Animals.explanationText: Hedgehogs curl up to protect themselves.

4. Adaptation in Animals.questionText: Which reptile can regrow its lost tail?
4. Adaptation in Animals.explanationText: Lizards regenerate tails when cut off.

4. Adaptation in Animals.questionText: Which desert animal comes out only at night?
4. Adaptation in Animals.explanationText: Scorpions are nocturnal to avoid heat.

4. Adaptation in Animals.questionText: Which bird can swim but cannot fly?
4. Adaptation in Animals.explanationText: Penguins are flightless but great swimmers.

4. Adaptation in Animals.questionText: Which mammal hangs upside down to sleep?
4. Adaptation in Animals.explanationText: Bats hang upside down to rest.

4. Adaptation in Animals.questionText: Which animal has humpback for storing fat?
4. Adaptation in Animals.explanationText: Camel’s hump stores fat, not water.

5. Food and Digestion.questionText: Which organ is called the 'food pipe'?
5. Food and Digestion.explanationText: The esophagus is also called the food pipe.

5. Food and Digestion.questionText: Where does digestion begin in the human body?
5. Food and Digestion.explanationText: Digestion starts in the mouth with chewing and saliva.

5. Food and Digestion.questionText: Which organ produces bile for digestion?
5. Food and Digestion.explanationText: The liver produces bile to help digest fats.

5. Food and Digestion.questionText: Which organ stores bile?
5. Food and Digestion.explanationText: The gallbladder stores bile from the liver.

5. Food and Digestion.questionText: Which enzyme in saliva helps digest starch?
5. Food and Digestion.explanationText: Saliva contains amylase which breaks down starch.

5. Food and Digestion.questionText: Where does most digestion take place?
5. Food and Digestion.explanationText: Most digestion and absorption happen in the small intestine.

5. Food and Digestion.questionText: Which organ absorbs water from undigested food?
5. Food and Digestion.explanationText: The large intestine absorbs water.

5. Food and Digestion.questionText: Which organ churns food and mixes it with digestive juices?
5. Food and Digestion.explanationText: The stomach churns food with juices for digestion.

5. Food and Digestion.questionText: Which organ produces insulin?
5. Food and Digestion.explanationText: The pancreas produces insulin and digestive juices.

5. Food and Digestion.questionText: Which part of the digestive system absorbs nutrients?
5. Food and Digestion.explanationText: The small intestine absorbs nutrients.

5. Food and Digestion.questionText: Which organ is called the largest gland of the body?
5. Food and Digestion.explanationText: The liver is the largest gland of the body.

5. Food and Digestion.questionText: Which type of teeth are used for biting food?
5. Food and Digestion.explanationText: Incisors are used for cutting and biting food.

5. Food and Digestion.questionText: Which type of teeth are used for tearing food?
5. Food and Digestion.explanationText: Canines are used for tearing food.

5. Food and Digestion.questionText: Which type of teeth are used for grinding food?
5. Food and Digestion.explanationText: Molars help in grinding food.

5. Food and Digestion.questionText: What is the main function of saliva?
5. Food and Digestion.explanationText: Saliva moistens food and contains amylase for starch digestion.

5. Food and Digestion.questionText: Which organ is also known as the 'energy factory'?
5. Food and Digestion.explanationText: The liver processes nutrients and gives energy.

5. Food and Digestion.questionText: What is the tube that connects the mouth to the stomach?
5. Food and Digestion.explanationText: The esophagus connects the mouth and stomach.

5. Food and Digestion.questionText: What is the main function of the stomach?
5. Food and Digestion.explanationText: The stomach churns and digests food.

5. Food and Digestion.questionText: Which organ helps in digesting fats?
5. Food and Digestion.explanationText: The liver produces bile to digest fats.

5. Food and Digestion.questionText: Which part of the digestive system is the longest?
5. Food and Digestion.explanationText: The small intestine is the longest part of the digestive system.

5. Food and Digestion.questionText: What is the main function of the large intestine?
5. Food and Digestion.explanationText: The large intestine absorbs water from undigested food.

5. Food and Digestion.questionText: Which organ produces digestive enzymes and insulin?
5. Food and Digestion.explanationText: The pancreas produces enzymes and insulin.

5. Food and Digestion.questionText: Which organ temporarily stores food?
5. Food and Digestion.explanationText: The stomach stores food temporarily.

5. Food and Digestion.questionText: Which type of teeth appear at the back of the mouth?
5. Food and Digestion.explanationText: Molars appear at the back of the mouth.

5. Food and Digestion.questionText: What is the process of breaking food into simpler substances called?
5. Food and Digestion.explanationText: Digestion is the process of breaking down food.

5. Food and Digestion.questionText: What is the role of bile in digestion?
5. Food and Digestion.explanationText: Bile helps break down fats into smaller droplets.

5. Food and Digestion.questionText: Which organ is known as the 'storehouse of energy'?
5. Food and Digestion.explanationText: The liver stores glycogen as energy.

5. Food and Digestion.questionText: What is the main function of the pancreas?
5. Food and Digestion.explanationText: The pancreas produces enzymes for digestion.

5. Food and Digestion.questionText: Which organ helps in swallowing food?
5. Food and Digestion.explanationText: The esophagus helps in swallowing food.

5. Food and Digestion.questionText: Which juice is secreted by the stomach?
5. Food and Digestion.explanationText: The stomach secretes gastric juice.

5. Food and Digestion.questionText: Which organ releases digestive juice into the small intestine?
5. Food and Digestion.explanationText: The pancreas releases digestive juice into the small intestine.

5. Food and Digestion.questionText: What happens to undigested food?
5. Food and Digestion.explanationText: Undigested food is removed as waste.

5. Food and Digestion.questionText: Which teeth help in chewing food properly?
5. Food and Digestion.explanationText: Molars help in chewing food.

5. Food and Digestion.questionText: Which part of the digestive system connects the stomach and large intestine?
5. Food and Digestion.explanationText: The small intestine connects stomach and large intestine.

5. Food and Digestion.questionText: Which organ makes digestive juices and stores vitamins?
5. Food and Digestion.explanationText: The liver stores vitamins and makes bile.

5. Food and Digestion.questionText: What is the function of villi in the small intestine?
5. Food and Digestion.explanationText: Villi absorb nutrients from digested food.

5. Food and Digestion.questionText: Which process moves food through the esophagus?
5. Food and Digestion.explanationText: Peristalsis is the movement of food in the esophagus.

5. Food and Digestion.questionText: What is gastric juice made of?
5. Food and Digestion.explanationText: Gastric juice contains hydrochloric acid and enzymes.

5. Food and Digestion.questionText: Which food nutrient gives us energy?
5. Food and Digestion.explanationText: Carbohydrates are the main source of energy.

5. Food and Digestion.questionText: Which nutrient builds our body?
5. Food and Digestion.explanationText: Proteins help in growth and repair.

5. Food and Digestion.questionText: Which nutrient keeps our body warm?
5. Food and Digestion.explanationText: Fats keep our body warm and provide energy.

5. Food and Digestion.questionText: Which nutrient protects us from diseases?
5. Food and Digestion.explanationText: Vitamins help us fight diseases.

5. Food and Digestion.questionText: Which nutrient is needed for strong bones and teeth?
5. Food and Digestion.explanationText: Calcium strengthens bones and teeth.

5. Food and Digestion.questionText: Which organ absorbs digested food into the blood?
5. Food and Digestion.explanationText: The small intestine absorbs digested food.

5. Food and Digestion.questionText: What happens to food in the mouth?
5. Food and Digestion.explanationText: Digestion begins in the mouth with saliva.

5. Food and Digestion.questionText: Which part of the digestive system removes waste food?
5. Food and Digestion.explanationText: The large intestine removes waste food.

5. Food and Digestion.questionText: What is the role of enzymes in digestion?
5. Food and Digestion.explanationText: Enzymes speed up chemical reactions of digestion.
